bib_record.title: Isotopic dependence of electron screening in fusion reactions

free_txt: - final publ., data tables
- data only on figs.
The accelerator (350 kV)
the accelerators (100 kV and 400 kV)
the accelerator (4 MV)
The energy spread:
+-0.020 keV for 100 kV accelerator.
+-0.3   keV for 350 kV accelerator.
+-1.0   keV for 400 kV and 4. MV accelerators.
Accelerators provided p, d, 6Li, and 7Li ion beams in
the c.m. energy range E = 10 to 1450 keV. At the lowest
energies, the p and d beam currents on target were
600 uA and those of the 6-Li and 7-Li beams were 40 uA.
At higher energies the currents were limited by
dead time effects in the detectors (kept below 3%) or
by requirements of the beam calorimeters. The
absolute ion beam energy of the accelerators is known
to sufficient precision and has been tested for the
350 and 400 KV accelerators during the course of the
experiments.

free_txt: Screening potential energies.
The fusion reactions 6Li(p,alpha)3He, 6Li(d,alpha)
4He, and 7Li(p,alpha) 4He have been studied over the
c.m. energy range E= 10 to 1450 keV. Each reaction
involved the use of hydrogen projectiles and LiF
solid targets as well as Li projectiles and hydrogen
molecular gas targets. In all cases the effects of
electron screening on the low-energy fusion cross
sections (exponential enhancement) have been
observed; the effects are somewhat stronger in the
case of atomic p or d projectiles compared to the
case of molecular H2 or D2 gas targets. If isotopic
effects on electron screening are negligible, all
three reactions should exhibit the same enhancements
for each set of experimental techniques. The
measurements confirmed this expectation to a large
extent.
The accelerator (350 kV)
the accelerators (100 kV and 400 kV)
the accelerator (4 MV)
The energy spread:
+-0.020 keV for 100 kV accelerator.
+-0.3   keV for 350 kV accelerator.
+-1.0   keV for 400 kV and 4. MV accelerators.
Accelerators provided p, d, 6Li, and 7Li ion beams in
the c.m. energy range E = 10 to 1450 keV. At the lowest
energies, the p and d beam currents on target were
600 uA and those of the 6-Li and 7-Li beams were 40 uA.
At higher energies the currents were limited by
dead time effects in the detectors (kept below 3%) or
by requirements of the beam calorimeters. The
absolute ion beam energy of the accelerators is known
to sufficient precision and has been tested for the
350 and 400 KV accelerators during the course of the
experiments.
Seven surface-barrier detectors were
placed at 30. to 135. degr.
Errors quoted arise from uncertainties in
number of counts, angular distributions, and
effective energy.
All values have an additional common error
of 7% due to
* uncertainties in proton beam (1% and 2.5%)
* uncertainties in pressure (2%), and
* uncertainty in target thickness and solid
angle 6.4%
Inverse kinematics
The hydrogen gas (H2 = 99.99% or D2 = 99.9%) was
not recirculated. The H2 (D2) gas pressure given above
was reduced to 1.8 x 10**(-2) (7.5 x 10**(-3)) mbar
and 1.8 x 10**(-5) (5 x 10**(-6)) mbar in the region
of the first and fourth pumping stage, respectively.
Disk-shaped target chamber (20 cm diameter,
3 cm height) was used.
Table 1 from Z.Phys.,A342(1992)471

Fig. 5 from Z.Phys.,A342(1992)471
In the case of 6Li(p,alpha)3He, the data are
dominated by an A1 coefficient, with a small A2
coefficient of the analytic form
No information about source of uncertainty
Fig. 6a from Z.Phys.,A342(1992)471
Due to the identical boson character of the ejectiles
in 6Li(d,alpha) 4He and 7Li(p,alpha) 4He, the
distributions are symmetrical about angle=90 degr.
and thus can be described by even Legendre
polynomials. Fits to the distributions of both
reactions have shown that the data can be described
sufficiently with an A2 coefficient (A4=~0) .
No information about source of uncertainty
Fig. 6b from Z.Phys.,A342(1992)471
Due to the identical boson character of the ejectiles
in 6Li(d,alpha) 4He and 7Li(p,alpha) 4He, the
distributions are symmetrical about angle=90 degr.
and thus can be described by even Legendre
polynomials. Fits to the distributions of both
reactions have shown that the data can be described
sufficiently with an A2 coefficient (A4=~0) .
No information about source of uncertainty
Fig. 6c from Z.Phys.,A342(1992)471
A pair of Si detectors (450 mm2 active area) was
placed at opposite sides to the beam axis, and with
each detector at a distance of 9 mm from the beam axis.
